_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies

World Class Distribution is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities.  This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility.  For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration system.  Only trained operators / refrigeration contractor are permitted to perform system operations.  World Class Distribution has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition.  All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility.  In addition, these programs incorporate emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur.  At such an event, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

World Class Distribution is located at 343 S. Lena Rd. in San Bernardino, California.  Ammonia is used in the facility's refrigeration system to provide cooling for the storage and distribution of grocery products.  The system uses a maximum of 25,000 pounds of ammonia.  A description of how the process operates is presented below:  

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of high pressure liquid ammonia from the High Pressure Receiver to the Accumulator / Flash Economizer (ACC1) and to the Dock and Temp Evaporators. The High Pressure Receiver also sends liquid ammonia to the Compressors for liquid injection oil cooling.  

At the Accumulator / Flash Economizer, the temperature of the liquid is lowered by the medium temperature suction prior to being fed to the rest of the system.  The subcooled liquid is then fed to the -10 Low Temp Recirculator (LTR2). Low temp recirculated liquid is then pumped to -30 Low Temp Recirculator (LTR1) and the Freezer and Turkey Evaporators. The -30 Low

recommendations.   In addition, the facility plans to continue providing employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.

Temp Recirculator pumps ultra low temp recirculated liquid to the Freezer Evaporators. 

Liquid ammonia flowing through the evaporator coils is partially boiled as it absorbs heat from the product and room. The resulting 'wet suction' (liquid/vapor mix) is sent to the following vessels. 
¿	Dock Evaporators → Accumulator / Flash Economizer (ACC1)
¿	Temp Evaporators → Accumulator (ACC2)
¿	Freezer & Turkey Evaporators → -10 Low Temp Recirculator (LTR2)
¿	Ice Cream Evaporators → -30 Low Temp Recirculator (LTR1)

These vessels are designed to prevent liquid ammonia from reaching the compressors based upon the temperature and application.  Excess liquid in the -30 Low Temp Recirculator drains to the associated Liquid Transfer Vessel.  Hot gas from the Compressors is used to push the liquid ammonia from the Liquid Transfer Vessel to the High Pressure Receiver.

Suction is pulled from the vessels by the Compressors. Compressor C1 pulls ultra low temp suction from the -30 Low Temp Recirculator. Compressors C2-C4 pull low temp suction from the -10 Low Temp Recirculator. Compressors C1-C4 also receive medium temp suction (economizer suction) from the Accumulator / Flash Economizer for increased efficiency. Compressor C5 is a swing compressor and can pull suction from any one of the 4 vessels. Compressor C6 pulls medium temp suction from the Accumulator / Flash Economizer. Compressors C7-C8 pull high temp suction from the Accumulator. The Compressors increase the pressure of the ammonia vapor through the discharge port of the machine. The Compressors send high-pressure discharge vapor to the Underfloor Heat Exchanger and Evaporative Condensers.  The high-pressure discharge is also routed to the Liquid Transfer Vessel (to pressurize the vessel and facilitate liquid transfer) and to the evaporators (air units AU1-AU45) for hot gas defrost.  The Compressors receive liquid ammonia from the High Pressure Receiver for liquid injection oil cooling.

Hot gas in the Underfloor Heat Exchanger is used to warm glycol used in a secondary loop for underfloor heating in the freezers. The resulting medium temp suction is sent to the Accumulator / Flash Economizer.

At the Condensers, air (fans) and water (pumps) are used to condense the compressor discharge into high pressure liquid, which then drains back to the High Pressure Receiver to begin the refrigeration cycle again.

An auto purger is provided to remove non-condensables from the high side of the system.  All relief valves are tied to a common header and relieve to the Ammonia Diffusion Tank.

World Class Distribution operates the refrigeration system at the facility 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Operations and preventative maintenance is conducted by the refrigeration contractor.

Accidental Release Prevention Program

World Class Distribution has developed an accidental release prevention program for compliance with the OES CalARP regulations.  The program includes but is not limited to the following elements:

¿	Safety information regarding the chemical hazards, and operating and technical specifications for the equipment;
¿	Written procedures for operating and maintaining the processes;
¿	Training for personnel involved with system operations and maintenance;
¿	Investigating releases and near misses and implementing measures to prevent recurrence; and
¿	Audit procedures for ensuring that the programs are being implemented in accordance to the regulations. 

In addition, engineering controls have been implemented to reduce the chance of an accidental release to the environment.  These are comprised of equipment monitoring systems and safety cutouts to shut off the equipment when operating parameters exceed safe operating limits.  Relief valves on pressurized ammonia vessels prevent equipment rupture in the event of overpressurization.  Regular inspections and tests are performed to ensure these controls are in good working order.

Fiv

e Year Accident History

As the facility is of new construction, a review of the facility's five year accident history showed that there have been no incidents at the facility that meet the RMP criteria for a reportable accident (onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place).  In addition, there have been no incidents at the facility in the last five years that resulted in a release of more than the Federal Reportable Quantity (100 pounds).

Emergency Response Program

World Class Distribution has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community.  The EAP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) dealing with an ammonia release and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and emergency response personnel, and 4) administering first aid measures for ammonia exposure.  Employees are informed of the elements of the EAP.  In the event of an ammonia release, employees will evacuate or shelter-in-place, depending on the nature of the release, and the facility will contact the refrigeration contractor (C&L Refrigeration, (800) 901-4822) and the fire department (San Bernardino County Fire Department, (909) 829-4441) for assistance as necessary.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

A Process Hazard Analysis and a Seismic Assessment have been performed on the ammonia refrigeration system, and these studies have resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility.  The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment.  World Class Distribution has implemented several of these action items and is moving forward with completing the remaining outstanding
